text: I made a side table that goes over the
arm of your sofa has some storage and
this is made out of just one board
this table is super simple to make but
there's one cool detail
I cut miters on these pieces to create
this continuous grain or waterfall
effect going over the side so normally
these miters would be reinforced with
something like a domino but I don't have
one of those and I know a lot of you
guys don't either so I used a hidden
spline instead so stick around if you're
interested to see how I did it I started
out by trimming up this canary wood
board that I received from woodworkers
source to the correct width that I
needed and then I marked out where I
needed to cut the pieces for the top of
the table that are going to require the
miter cuts I rough cut the boards to
length and then I considered making a
new sweat that's going to cut miters in
these boards but then I just decided to
create a slot that's going to cut the
miter on my existing crosscut sled
I broke the piece onto the sled and it's
easy to line up your cut line with the
kerf on the fence of the sled so I
clamped it down at the back and then I
used some more clamps at the front to
put some pressure down on the front of
the board that way these miters will be
perfectly accurate all along the cut in
order to create the waterfall feature of
these miters the next board needs to be
cut with the miter cut on the opposite
side of the board so I flipped it over
lined it up again with the kerf on the
sled you want to line it up a right at
the edge of that first cut that you made
I clamped it down to make sure that it
was even again and then cut away the cut
off of this piece should be a perfect
triangle if you're doing it correctly
there are going to be two waterfall
features on this table of one at the top
one at the bottom so I continued cutting
the rest of the pieces the same way as I
did before
cut one miter flip the piece over and
then cut the miter on the meeting piece
right all the miters are cut now I need
a way to join all these pieces so I made
this quick little jig out of a scrap
piece of plywood I just cut one miter
that same angle so that I could create a
sled at the router table then I cut
these little triangles that are just
going to act as support blocks for the
jig this jig has two pieces of plywood
one has the miter on the front of it
facing up the other has
later at the bottom leaning towards the
back of the jig so I glued and used some
Brad nails to get it all into place and
then I glued all those support pieces in
the back I wanted to make sure that
there was enough room to put a clamp
there so that those support blocks did
not get in the way of clamping my
material the last step in making this
jig is just to put on some sort of stop
or hold her on the end so I took a scrap
piece of poplar cut that same 45 degree
on one of the ends and then just glued
it on to the back edge of the jig this
is just going to create a kind of like
holder for the work pieces so that
they're always in the correct position
all right the jig is done now time to
set it up I moved the fence all the way
back on my router table put the jig in
place then put my workpiece on raise the
bit to a quarter-inch I and then moved
it towards the center of the board so
that it won't cut all the way through
now the bit is at the correct height the
fence is in the correct position now I
just need to create some stop locks so
that I couldn't plunge the cut and stop
it on the correct locations so I put the
board on it marked about a half inch
from either side of the board and then I
clamp the board onto the jig leaving a
space so that I could move it on top of
the bit so I could locate where the
start and stopping points are after
moving the board so that the half-inch
line that I had drawn was in line with
the edge of the bit I clamped down a
stop and then moved it over to the other
line that I made and repeated the same
thing now it's time to cut all I had to
do was take the jig plunge it on to the
bit move it to the end stop block and
then remove it repeated the same thing
on the other pieces and it worked out
really great I had what issue when it
came to the smallest middle section of
the box because I did not have any good
surface area for clamping so I thought
that I would be able to use some sort of
like stopper piece and double-side tape
it so that it has more pressure to clamp
against but there was a gap on the
underside of the jig and I didn't like
that so I decided to use some other
clamps so that I could get some clamping
pressure in the correct location for
these pieces so I just found these
random clamps that I had lying around
and they don't match but they work and
then I was able to clamp and miss
center of that board and that totally
eliminated the gap in the bottom between
the workpiece of the jig alright sigh of
relief that I figured out a solution and
then I was easily able to cut the
grooves in that smaller piece I did it
on one side ran it along using those
stop blocks as a guide and then did it
to the other side moving on to the
splines so if you're not using plywood
you need to make sure that the wood that
you're using for the splines has the
same grain direction because it's going
to expand in two different directions
that's not good so I found the widest
piece of scrap that I had so that I
could cut off a spline from the end of
it so the grain would be the same this
board was just too short to fit into my
planer so I had to attach it onto a sled
with some double-sided tape I also taped
on a sacrificial backer piece just to be
safe and also it helps to reduce some
snipe so then I just ran the pieces
through my planer until they were the
perfect thickness to fit into the
grooves I just had to be really careful
when removing it because it was very
thin so now to get the correct width I
measured the inside of the groove and
then put that measurement on to that
scrap piece of oak and then I cut it at
the crosscut sled at my table saw now
the grooves that I made are round
because they're made by a router bit so
I decided to just take a block plane and
round off all those edges instead of
squaring up the grooves now there's a
perfect fit I just need to cut them all
to length so in order to get the correct
length
I used my combination square and then
just multiplied that by to cut it to
length and now it's finally time to test
fit I placed the spline in the grooves
and then put the mating piece in it was
so satisfying to see this joint just
come together so seamlessly so all the
hard stuff is done and now I just have
to finish cutting the rest on the table
before I can assemble it all I cut the
last two pieces at the miter saw and now
all five of the pieces are ready to be
assembled I started with the base
because that's the easiest part so I use
the center finding ruler to find the
center of both of the boards that are
going to be connected and that way when
I line up the two pieces it's just easy
to connect those two pencil marks to
make sure that everything is nice and
center to assemble the main stand onto
the base of the table I use some
and don't worry I'm going to reinforce
this joint a little bit later so this is
where those pencil lines come in handy I
could just place the board onto those
pencil lines making sure that they're
even and then I used some corner clamps
to make sure that they will be ninety
degrees to each other see how I can
easily line it up to make sure it's
centered I did one side first and then
repeated the same thing to the other
side once that glue set up a little bit
I flip the table over use some clamps to
help support it and then I marked off
where the middle section board was so
that I couldn't drill some holes for
some dowels
I used an awl to mark out all the
locations for the dowels and I'm going
to use a good Brad point bit that I can
use in conjunction with this drilling
guide block so I couldn't put the tip of
the bit into the hole made by the awl
and then I used the drilling guide lock
to help me drill completely straight
into the bottom and the support stand of
the table all the other joinery on this
table is going to be hidden but I didn't
really care if these dowels were showing
because it's the bottom of the table and
nobody will ever see it I placed glue in
all the holes and then use the screw to
just spread the glue all the way around
and then banged all the dowels into
place this creates a very strong bond
between the base and stand after the
glue set up a little bit I just use a
flush trim saw and I cut away at all the
excess now this part is done moving on
to the miters the top part of the table
needs to be assembled in stages I
started with the middle section of the
box and the bottom part of the box I put
on a ton of glue on the miter joint and
then placed the spline in place and then
repeated the same thing on the other end
of the miter joint making sure I got a
ton of glue in the groove there and then
I used some tape to temporarily clamp
these pieces together I know that I
could have made some angled clamping
calls to try to get these together but I
wanted to see if I could just make do
with what I had so I put those corner
clamps on and then I could put an angled
piece inside that corner clamp to create
a parallel surface for clamps to clamp
against and then I was able to close up
those miters from either side
the piece there was a little bit crazy
but it worked the only reason why this
was able to work was because of that
angled scrap that I was able to wedge in
there into the corner clamps otherwise I
wouldn't have a parallel surface because
of that miter so now moving on to the
rest of the joinery I'm going to use
some dowels I use the center finding
dowel jig to drill some holes in the end
of the bottom box piece and then to make
the matching holes that are going to go
in the stand I'm gonna use some dowel
points but in order to get those dowel
points in the correct location I had to
temporarily just put the top of the
table onto the side of the table and
clamp it into place that way I can get
all those dowel points into the holes
that I just made and then I can carry
the whole thing over to the table get it
to the correct height and then push the
points in to the side at the table it's
hard to see on video but those points
leave over a little hole so that leaves
a guide for where to put the brad point
bit to make the corresponding holes for
the dowels I repeated the same process
to connect the top of the table to the
main stand I use the center finding
dowel guide to drill holes in the top of
the main stand then I put the dowel
points into those holes and then in
order to get them to be in the correct
position for the top of the board I
temporarily put the bottom part of the
box clamped it on to the main stand
using the dowels put the spline in place
and then lowered the top on to the
points I was slightly concerned that
because of that angle it would not match
up but it ended up working out perfectly
so once again I use the Brad point bit
with the drilling guide block to draw
the corresponding holes and now it is
time to assemble this all had to be done
in stage heads as well so I put glue and
dowels into the bottom of the box piece
put glue on all those dowels and then
place them into side of the support
piece into the holes that I made and
then I couldn't clamp that all up next I
put glue on to the top of that side
piece on the miter and inside the groove
and then place the spline into place
then I put glue in the devil holes and
in the top of the means
Pease put all the dowels in and I also
made sure to put some glue on top of
those dowels and then I placed the top
board on using some clamps to hold down
the top of the board onto the main
support piece and then I got to clamping
up all those miters so this all had
parallel edges that I could clamp
against so that I was able to clamp from
side to side and top to bottom this was
a little bit nerve-wracking but when I
got them all on sigh of relief I set
that off to dry overnight and when I got
all those clamps off and saw how awesome

how this was turning out now the last

finishing up the table speaking of
learning new skills I decided to whip

sandpaper and it was such a smooth
finish I am definitely going to use my
card scraper more often for the miters I
needed to be really careful not to take
off too much material so I
just broke the edges with some 220 grit
sandpaper to get them really smooth and
sanded all the inside edges as well
before finishing I wiped the whole table
down with some mineral spirits and this
takes off all the dust and it makes it
perfectly clean for finishing I decided
to go with a wipe-on poly because it's
just a really easy application you just
wipe it on and let it dry sand with 220
and then put on a second coat the grain
popping on this was so satisfying this
canary wood is so gorgeous and it's done
I love how simple and functional this
